div.span:
Calls to our API(s)/
has quantifiable user interactions
Time spent on our application
Data volume streamed/processed

number of complex
calculations/creation of software packages/etc.
that we have to perform based on
the number of different regions/models/etc. we service
Users/connected devices

We don't scale much/at all,
our usage remains (basically) static,
even if more people use us

By sales. Users on the site
that do not buy anything don't
cause much load
Yes
No
Yes
No
Yes
No
No
It does not even out
It evens out
Yes
No
Yes
No
Yes
Yes

No, it would make
quite a difference

They are all quite similar,
both in terms of price and computing effort

They are quite different from each other,
either/both in terms of price and/or computing effort
Yes
No
Yes
No
Yes
No
Yes
No
No, never

Oh,
no over that timeframe
it does even out
Yes
No
Yes
No, one could be ignored
Yes, both matter

Answer the following questions
as best and leniently as you can.
Feel free to go back up the path
if you think you ended up somewhere
that does not make sense

What does your software
scale with? If several apply,
pick the one you think has
the closest correlation

And do those API calls cause
roughly the same amount of computing effort?

And the time spent there
by different users causes roughly
the same amount of effort?

Then your best fitting functional
unit might be data volume
R = per Kb/Mb/Gb streamed

So adding users or connected devices
would have a minimal effect compared to adding
regions/models/etc.?

Users/connected devices might be
the right unit, but we should make sure
that it is not a lesser proxy for some
of the other suggestions.

Then your best fitting functional
unit might be runtime
R = per sec/min/h
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

How different are sales from each other?
Determining if by sale or by € should
be your functional unit can be a bit tricky

Then your best fitting functional
unit might be API calls.
R = per API call
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

Do the expensive and cheap calls
occur in a somewhat consistent ratio?

Does their ratio fluctuate
based on a consistent pattern?
Could we statistically normalise
them over a given timeframe?

Then we just have to take the
CO2eq created over that timeframe and divide it by API calls
to use API calls as your probably best fitting functional unit.
R = per API calls
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

Sounds like either a special and tricky problem,
or maybe at some point
a wrong path was taken in the flow chart.
Please contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.

Does this even out over time?
Or does the power needed fluctuate
somewhat independent of the number
of users on the application?

Do the things users do
result in something like API Calls
or another kind of action that is countable?

Then your best fitting functional
unit is probably time spent on application
R = per sec
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

Go to the top and choose
the 'Calls to our API' option as your path

Can there be made any other kind of classification
of users or their actions that could put them
in categories that statistically can be evened out?

Then a functional unit must be created,
that takes that categorisation and time spent
on the application into account,
e.g. something like CO2eq per premium user
second and per normal user second averaged
out by the current ratio of the two,
even if that ratio fluctuates.
Please contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.

Sounds like either a special and tricky problem,
or maybe at some point
a wrong path was taken in the flow chart.
Please contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.

Then number of those regions/models/etc.
might be your best functional unit.
This case is less clear than some of the others,
please check over time if this does
not create misaligned incentives,
and perform some checks right now
to see if this functional unit
really works for you
R = number of regions/models/etc.
the calculations/creation is done for

So are both the number of users/devices
and the number of models/regions/etc.
that have to do these costly operations for
relevant factors for the amount of
computing load that is required,
so neither of which can be ignored?

In that case per sale might be
a better functional unit for you than per €
It would not be affected by inflation,
but changes in your business model might affect it.
Be sure to check if
R = per sale
is still the right unit for you every
time you adjust your business model.
Also you can do some checks right now
to be more sure about it

Does the ratio stay about the same?
Is there a relative stable € per sale ratio?

Then per € might be a good functional unit for you.
It would be affected by inflation,
so your SCI would rise slowly over time
without your software getting worse, unless
you adjust for it. It is also sensitive
to changes in your business model,
or changing consumer behavior,
so be mindful of that as well.
R = per (inflation adjusted) €
You can do some checks right now to
be more sure if this R is right for you

Do you have a way of differentiating
active from inactive users/devices and
excluding them from the analysis?

And each user/device causes a
similar load/it averages out?

In that case we really should not use
users/connected devices as our R,
as inactive users piling up would lower the SCI,
without any improvements

Does your application receive
API-Calls/quantifiable interactions from its users?

Go to the top and choose
the 'Calls to our API' option as your path

Anything that can be used as the proxy
for what creates computing load?
Something that active users/devices do
and inactive ones don't

Okay,
R = active users/devices
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

The load does not even out
over any timeframe? Not over a day, month or year even?

Okay, then you just need
to average out your use over the required timeframe,
and you can use
R = active users/devices
Perform some checks to see if this
really works for you

Can you find it in the top row?
Maybe time spent on the application
or user interactions?

Sounds like either a special and tricky problem,
or maybe at some point
a wrong path was taken in the flow chart.
Please contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.

Go to the top and choose
the relevant option as your path

Then there was a mistake in answering
one of the questions before,
please go back up the path or
contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.

That is a tricky situation,
in the worst case we would have to
view the application as 2 separate analytical units.
But maybe this can be avoided.
Please contact our experienced consultants
to discuss this further with them.
